title: Is postmodernism a harmful ideology? - Quora

response.answer_text: In postmodernism, ideas are “social constructs” which competing pressure groups use to oppress one another and impose their power over one another. Postmodernists tend to believe that there is no actual reality, or that human concepts are unable to describe it, so everything is subjective, made up by the human mind. Postmodernism - Postmodernism and relativism As a consequence, if someone is trying to persuade you of some idea which you do not believe, or contradicts what you believe, that person is trying to oppress you, or is a representative of some oppressive group. To a postmodernist, whites have their own truth and logic, and blacks have theirs, and both are equally valid. Western civilization has science, and primitive witch doctors have their own science, which is also just as valid, even if they claim they can alter the weather through their primitive rituals.  The working class has their truth, and the rich capitalists have their ideas about free markets, laissez-faire, emergent order, and increased productivity providing people with continually improving prosperity, which are just their means to keep the working poor under control. To a postmodernist, all argumentation is just a mind game used in conflict between competing groups. As long as there are different groups, there will be conflict. The consequence is that there are just two ways to deal with conflict. You eliminate the differences which create these pressure groups, or you just periodically have the oppressors and oppressed switch places. The first way is exemplified by the Nazis or Soviets. Although their ideologies long preceded the postmodernists such as Derrida and Foucault, they agreed that logical arguments are weapons in class or race conflicts. The solution to conflict was to eliminate all but one class or race. Thus, the Soviets tried to eliminate the “Bourgeoisie” and the Kulaks, while the Nazis tried to exterminate the Jews and other unwanted racial minorities. More gentle postmodernists simply try to eliminate different warring groups by bringing them together, trying to eliminate the distinctions which separate them. This requires social engineering and mental reconditioning to persuade people that there is no such thing as gender, or that there are no IQ differences between racial groups, or even within racial groups. The solution to eliminate conflict is to make everyone the same.   To achieve this, dissent cannot be tolerated. Any idea of objective truth or difference of opinion is a source of “oppression”. Discourse is “oppression”, but if everyone agrees, if everyone has the same ideas, there is no need for discourse. See the comments by postmodernist Chris Pierce below my answer. Others seem to want to perpetuate the conflict by having the oppressed and the oppressors switch places. No matter how much white people have paid in the past for slavery, no matter how hard many white people have worked to achieve equality under the law, more reparations are demanded. Either way, conflict cannot actually be eliminated. Postmodernism overturns the ideas of the Enlightenment, which say that there is an objective reality, that we can come to know it, and that if there is a conflict between two people, they should either settle it through persuasion, or go their separate ways. Under Enlightenment principles, people can live in peace so long as they do not use violence against one another. Toleration is possible, even necessary, to allow negotiation and discourse, and for people to live in peace when discourse does not settle their differences. Postmodernism makes such peaceful coexistence between men with different ideas impossible. Their different ideas are only their means to try to oppress one another. The only hope the oppressed have is to switch places with their oppressors, become the oppressors themselves. If I believed postmodernist nonsense, I would be a male chauvinist, white supremacist, homophobic, American fascist. Instead, I am a libertarian who believes that each individual should be judged on his own merits, that we should eliminate the initiation of coercive violence from society, that the state should be minimized, maybe eliminated altogether as an institution of coercion, and that we should celebrate our differences, living together in tolerance if not appreciation of our differences. But under postmodernism, that is impossible. In fact, a postmodernist would conclude that I actually AM a male chauvinist, white supremacist, homophobic, American fascist. A postmodernist would conclude that my support for laissez-faire capitalism is just an ideology made up and accepted because I am some rich capitalist who loves oppressing the workers. The enlightenment (the “modern” in postmodernism) has gives us the most prosperous society in history. It has brought us relative peace, reduced child mortality, prolonged life expectancies, and provided us with a vast amount of wealth and comfort.  Postmodernism would destroy all of that.  Postmodernism is what is behind the SJW phenomenon and the rise of Antifa.  These SJWs cannot tolerate dissent. They are uninterested in learning the ideas of people they oppose. They aren’t interested in finding out if someone they don’t like has a valid point to make, or facts to back them up. They don’t care. They see your attempts to engage them with fact and logic as an attempt to oppress them, so their only possible response is to try to oppress you right back. Freedom of speech is seen as just an excuse to defend oppressive ideas. The only solution they have is violence.  So, yeah. Postmodernism is harmful to society. It rips society apart into warring factions and destroys any means by which peaceful coexistence can be achieved.

Postmodernism is not a harmful ideology. Why? Because postmodernism is not an ideology. If the concept of ideology means anything at all, it refers to a program or system of thought that addresses itself not only to a specially trained elite (as in the case of “scholastic” philosophy), nor to a literate middle-class readership (the popular philosophy of the Enlightenment), but to all of society, providing a general framework, applicable to all, for how to live. Ideology, in this way, demands complex processes by which “esoteric” philosophical or scientific ideas are translated into forms that make them accessible even to an illiterate or (with universal literacy) semi-literate audience. Esoteric ideas get translated into popular political movements, educational programs reaching down to the lowest levels, and also coercive state violence. In this sense, moreover, ideology is the telos of philosophy — or, indeed, we could speak of a kind of entropy in the realm of ideas. It is almost unnatural for a powerful idea to remain constrained to a small segment of the population, even if this segment remains the only one who can understand it. But at the same time, philosophers, to the extent that they’ve recognized the tendency of their ideas toward exoteric diffusion, have sought to “innoculate” these ideas from within, not only by insisting on a distinction between genuine understanding and popular misunderstanding, but by insisting on the impossibility of genuine understanding ever taking a perfectly communicable form. (“The Dao that can be spoken is not the enduring Dao”) In the Ancient world, the tendency of the development of ideology culminated in Christianity. Plato, who had already made a rather clumsy attempt to turn his own philosophy into ideology while at the same time upholding its esoteric purity, served as the “oven” of ideology: Platonism and Neo-Platonism made it possible for the most diverse cultural and religious elements to get baked together into a single theological-political solution. Modernity began when irreparable fissures appeared in the Catholic ideology. These fissures took many forms. On the one hand, a few esoteric ideas challenging late-Medieval scholasticism — a philosophy that had taken upon itself the task of preserving the ideological integrity of Christianity under the pressure of the new learning that was flooding in from the periphery while replacing the “volatile” Plato with the sedate “Aristotle” — laid the groundwork for the scientific revolution, which resulted in an understanding of the world that, impossible to refute, directly challenged the existing ideological formation. On the other hand, the Reformation, while insisting on a return to the more fundamental truth of Christianity, exploded the political-theological apparatus that had emerged during Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages. Specifically, it challenged the idea of institutional mediation: it challenged the very mode of Ideology… It replaced this with textual mediation. So, in essence, you have two things: 1) an esoteric scientific challenge to the essential kernel of the Christian world view: the relation of the unique human soul to God as creator. 2) a new mode of ideological consensus — textual mediation — which challenges the entire framework of the Catholic church, and its claim to authority, and yet, far from challenging the essential kernel of the Christian world view, “doubles down” on it. Science develops toward the popular philosophy of the Enlightenment. Classical liberalism may be seen as a “half-baked” ideology: half-baked, because it did not seek to replace the Christian kernel with scientific rationality, but rather to contain it within a framework of tolerance and a kind of utilitarian rationality. This can even be seen in the illiberal Hobbes, whose message is already ideological in the sense that, while expressed more geometrico, it speaks to everyone. Rousseau is also a “half-baked” ideology, though it goes further than the English and Scottish enlightenment in seeking a kind of synthesis. But, for all his brilliance, it lacks the philosophical wherewithal. Enter Kant! Enter German Idealism — and Hegel, above all! Hegel’s idealism is the great oven of ideology… It offers a powerful new way to connect “everyday life” with the most esoteric truth. And yet this ideological oven is still fueled by a hidden Christian kernel. Enter the Young Hegelians! Enter Marx! Marx offers, in germ, the first account of how a thoroughly secular scientific rationality can offer an overarching “ethics” of life. (This is not to deny that a certain theological eschatology underlies Marx’s view of history — it remains a work-in-progress. But this eschatology is not essential) to it) But Marx was only the basis of ideology, the germ of ideology. To become ideology, something more was needed: Marx had to become Marxism, a revolutionary program… (Marxism is, I think, a dimension of Marx — one shouldn’t seek an artificial separation between Marxian thought and Marxism). Marxism is thus the first “fully-baked” ideology to stand against Christianity. But Marxism quickly gives rise to a counter-ideology: Fascism, and the specifically Racialist ideologies of National Socialism. (The role of Nietzsche in this is very complex; he was more a philosopher than Marx, but he also clearly recognized the ideological potential of his thought and the danger this posed.) Moreover, the old order doesn’t go quietly: Fundamentalism emerges as a kind of counter-ideology to the ideologies of Modernity. And at the same time: liberalism, realizing that it is too “half-baked” to stand up to post-Enlightenment ideological complexes, seeks to reinvent itself as a “fully-baked” ideology. And so you get neo-Liberalism (von Hayek’s principle of self-organization offers a kind of scientific foundation), Ayn Rand… And, especially in the US, an bizarre alliance between Fundamentalism and Neo-Liberalism in which, in the name of liberalism, the true virtues of liberalism, its sanity and tolerance, are abandoned for fanaticism. Post-modernism emerged in the wake of the second world war. It is not an ideology, but a counter-ideology: a rejection of the hegemonic historical narratives that, baked in a Hegelian oven, underwrote the ideologies that emerged in the 19th and 20th century. Of course, it also opposed Christianity as ideology — but not Christian belief per se. One could even say that post-modernism sought a return to the epistemic modesty that one finds in Locke. Of course, post-modernism also challenges the claims of science, but only in so far as they present themselves as a new ideology —-passing from science to scientism. But now we have people like Hicks and Jordan Peterson. They are both neo-liberal ideologues: they seek to marshal all the powers of ideology in order to elevate “classical Liberalism” to an all-encompassing world view. (JP indeed offers a comprehensive account of “meaning,” and speaks to a non-Academic audience) And, as such, they oppose Marxism. But at the same time: they can’t admit that they speak for an ideology. They want to present their ideology as an anti-ideology. (But this is the sleight-of-hand of Neoliberalism —- it presents itself as natural, unproblematic, common sense) Hence it is necessary for them to present post-modernism, which is basically a critique of ideology, as an “conspiratorial” extension of Marxism. In order to present their own dogmatic “return” to liberalism by way of a social-Darwinian scientism as a non-ideology, they need to neutralize the critique of scientism by painting it as ideology par excellence. For just this reason, however, I would argue that postmodernism is dangerous — not because it is a dangerous ideology, but because, as a non-ideology, it is incapable of confronting either the need for ideology or the present danger of ideology. It is worth noting that communist revolutions have only succeeded in countries where institutional mediation rather than textual mediation was the norm: Russia, Catholic countries in South America, East Asia… Western Marxism (what JP misunderstands as “cultural Marxism”) is really “textual Marxism.” Against the barbarism of institutional mediation (violence, mass ritual, reducation camps) it sought a textual solution… It is this critical gesture, rather than the “institutional”, Statist ambitions, that led to the morphing of Marxism into post-modernism… Deconstruction, in particular, is the apotheosis of the textual critique of institutional power. But Jordan Peterson gets this all mixed up - deliberately, I think… At the same time, though, Leftism never really managed to develop an alternative to positive rather than merely critical textual mediation. Liberalism, in contrast, drawing on Protestantism, did. Western Marxism, by returning the rich philosophical traditions of the long 18th century — a tradition that was suppressed by dogmatic Marxism — sought to do this, but these philosophical currents, on the one hand, remained too esoteric, and, on the other hand, this attempt was undermined by the critical vigilance of deconstruction. And so we are left with a void. At the present moment, textual mediation, by way of social networking, has rapidly gained an hitherto unimaginable power. Institutional mediation is nearly meaningless. (This is the real meaning of all the talk about post-truth). Leftism has simply not been in a situation to assert itself in this situation. And yet, more than ever, ideology is needed. We live at a moment in which humanity is faced with an existential threat to its existence. There is a pressing need for a way of understanding how the ethical life of the individual can understand itself in relation to the fragility of the earth, and for a global politics of ecological responsibility grounded in economic and social justice. Post-modernism cannot provide this, and its failure has opened the door wide for new forms of fascism.
